programmes.show_name: And The Academy Award Goes To ...
programmes.show_description: 1/4. Paul Gambaccini explores how The Godfather, and it's successful sequel won Best Picture Oscars. With James Caan. From 2009.
4 Extra Debut. Bernard Cribbins profiles Mollie Millest, who wrote many radio scripts for Kenneth Horne and later Beyond Our Ken. From 2008.
1/6. 4 Extra Debut. When tragedy strikes horse racing, jockey Rob Finn uncovers a world of fear, rumour and bad intentions. Stars Michael Kitchen.
6/6. Rockingham is dead. As the French pirate awaits execution, Dona risks everything for the man she loves. Stars Lorna Heilbron.
2/6. Fulton Jones resumes his old ways in the family home after his mystery absence of 20 years. Stars Robin Bailey. From June 1980.
9/20. A movie and an illicit cheese supper sparks Mainwaring's own Waterloo. Adapted from BBC TV. With Arthur Lowe. From 1975.
1/4. 4 Extra Debut. Edinburgh widower Leo is surprised to meet a woman from his past - all he expected was a haircut. Stars Mark Bonnar. From 2021.
1/10. 4 Extra Debut. Betty leaves her husband during the Great Depression to return to her warm and noisy family in Seattle. Read by Debora Weston.
1/5. Vera nabs a package to Ibiza, and Irene aims to save her friend from seduction. Starring Prunella Scales and Patricia Routledge.
Roy Plomley challenges Eleanor Summerfield, Gillian Reynolds, David Nixon and Tim Rice to spot the mistakes. From August 1978.
4/6. Going for a drive through a time anomaly, Robin, Lesley and Dirk end up in Texas. Stars Hugh Bonneville. From July 2001.
An imagining of the impact of an over-bearing, bed-ridden mother on artist LS Lowry. Stars Lynda Baron and Reece Dinsdale.
4 Extra Debut. A holiday in the sun isn't the relaxing break one couple were expecting. Read by Chris Reilly.
2/6. Can jockey Rob Finn recover from his attack and discover who is behind the theft of racing information? Stars Michael Kitchen.
A rookie blackmailer is taught the ropes, but learns the pitfalls of the business. Starring Gerald Flood and Cyril Shaps.
1/8. A mystery body strains the Republic's spirit of glasnost at the British Embassy. Stars Dinsdale Landen. From March 1988.
14/17. Professor Ned Quatermass unravels a mystery around some enigmatic blue serge suits. Stars Spike Milligan. From February 1959.
4/4. All grandkids make mistakes, but only Jack and Millie's do it so loudly - and on video. Stars Jeremy Front. From 2018.
2/10. Mary gets hers sister Betty a job as a shorthand typist, but the trouble is she can't write in shorthand nor type! Read by Debora Weston.
2/5. Irene is forced into casual labour in Ibiza when she inherits Vera's debts. Stars Prunella Scales and Patricia Routledge.
6/6. Chris McCausland asks a panel of comedians to live in an audio only world. With Rhys James, Roisin Conaty, Zoe Lyons and Nabil Abdulrashid.
2/5. Joanna Pinnock explores the dual role of the enigmatic wolf, as protector and predator of our ancestors. From 1999.
A space for spiritual reflection with a Bible reading, prayer and a range of Christian music led by Angela Tilby.
4 Extra Debut. Laurie Anderson, Stuart Maconie and Harriett Gilbert discuss books by Hunter S Thompson, LTC Rolt and James Lever. From 2020.
Martin Reeve, known on the streets as Mr Lucky, charts the story of street theatre from the turbulent 1960s to today. From 2011.

6/8. The antiques quiz visits Syon House in London. With Lars Tharp, John Bly and Christine Lalumia. From May 1998.
3/6. Eliott must promote a German chocolate named 'Laughing', but he finds little humour in it. Stars Michael Brandon. From 2009.
Retiring teacher Andrew Crocker-Harris is also on the verge of divorce. Where does his future lie? Stars John Gielgud. From 1957.

1/4. John welcomes Chris Difford from Squeeze - not before he's ejected Ken who's got new windows. Stars Graham Fellows. From 2016.
From 10pm until midnight, seven days a week, the Comedy Club has two hours of comedy. Plus Ria Lina chats again to stand-up comedian Mark Simmons.
1/4. Comedian Paul Sinha looks at celebrity deaths, and the contribution of immigrants to American history. From 2017.
1/6. The actress and her writing partner/big brother in the talk tag show where the guest is the next interviewer. From 2012.

Trevor uses his acting skills when Miss Pike hires him to escort her on a works outing. Stars Brenda Bruce and Bernard Horsfall.
2/5. The Parish council needs its money, but will the bank be able to pay out? Political satire with John Baddeley. From July 1991.
14/14. When he hears his sound-alike in a TV commercial, the lad heads straight to court. Stars Tony Hancock. From December 1959.
2/6. Rupert Hardacre returns to his ad agency with a new outlook and a new soulmate. Stars Nigel Havers. From 2021.
3/10. Mary sets her sister Betty up on a string of disastrous dates. Read by Debora Weston.
3/5. Still on her package holiday, Vera is abducted by Transylvanian separatists. Stars Patricia Routledge and Prunella Scales.
3/6. Milton is recruited by the kindliest Secret Service in the world to oversee a tense spy swap on the Severn Bridge.
3/5. They are linked to the moon and were sacred in Roman times. Joanna Pinnock finds out more about the mad March hare. From 1999.
A space for spiritual reflection with a Bible reading, prayer and a range of Christian music led by Holly Adams.
4 Extra Debut. Emeli Sande explores the impact of Marvin Gaye's classic 1971 album What's Going On, and its continuing relevance. From 2021.

4/6. Starting with a television quiz show in 1990, and ending with a fairytale walk in 1921. With Carrie Quinlan. From 2021.
1/4. Liam adjusts to an alien new environment, Cambridge University. Autobiographical sitcom of youthful misadventures. From 2017. Contains strong language.
